project_metadata.paper_title: Measure Twice, Cut Once: Cooperative Deployment of a Generalized, Archaeology-Specific Field Data Collection System
project_metadata.journal: In: Mobilizing the Past for a Digital Future: The Potential of Digital Archaeology, edited by Erin Walcek Averett, Jody Michael Gordon, and Derek B. Counts, pp. 337-371. Grand Forks, ND: The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota
project_metadata.research_context: Three archaeological project directors report their experiences co-developing and deploying customised implementations of the FAIMS mobile platform for field data collection. Case studies include a Neolithic tell excavation in Turkey (Boncuklu Höyük), a Middle Stone Age project in Malawi (MEMSAP), and a late Prehispanic/early Colonial excavation in Peru (PAZC).

key_dates: January 2015: FAIMS moved to Macquarie University
2014: Field deployments at three partner sites

development_base: University of New South Wales, Sydney

resources.in_kind: approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS project launched in 2012 with NeCTAR funding of AUD $949,500
evidence.verbatim_quote: It was initially based at the University of New South Wales, Sydney, and funded by a grant from the Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500).

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS mobile platform entered public beta release in November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: the FAIMS project developed a generalised, mobile, offline, multi-user collection platform for structured, free-text, geospatial, and multimedia data (the 'FAIMS mobile platform,' discussed below), which entered public beta release in November 2013.

evidence.evidence_text: Second phase of FAIMS funded by ARC LIEF award totaling AUD $945,000
evidence.verbatim_quote: In 2014, the FAIMS project received an Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities (LIEF) award (LE140100151; AUD $945,000 total ARC funding and university co-investment)

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS 2.0 released in November 2014
evidence.verbatim_quote: Experience from these deployments informed ongoing development of FAIMS software, resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

evidence.evidence_text: Service fees account for about 5% of FAIMS budget, infrastructure grants constitute 95%
evidence.verbatim_quote: To date, fees have accounted for about 5% of the FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting the other 95%—although these figures exclude in-kind contributions of time by academic staff and other participants, which, for example, total approximately $100,000 per year at Macquarie University alone.

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS team has created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since November 2013
evidence.verbatim_quote: Most users, however, have chosen to purchase customisation and support services from the FAIMS team; to date, we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: FAIMS server infrastructure available through purchase (AUD $1,700-$3,500) or lease (AUD $150-$200/month)
evidence.verbatim_quote: Purchasing a pre-configured local server with all necessary hardware costs AUD $1,700–$3,500 from one of these vendors (excluding tablets). Alternatively, an online or local server can be leased for approximately AUD $150–$200 per month.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items support same claims with same pattern, from same paragraph; server cost options are a single finding

evidence.evidence_text: Module customisation costs approximately AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season depending on complexity
evidence.verbatim_quote: When a project hires the FAIMS team to adapt an existing module or develop a new one, this service generally costs approximately AUD $1,500–$15,000 per season for the mobile platform, depending on the complexity and novelty of the recording system required.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu and MEMSAP customisation and support valued at about $15,000 each for first year
evidence.verbatim_quote: Customisation and support work for the Boncuklu and MEMSAP projects presented here, for example, was valued about $15,000 each for their first year of deployment (but only $3,250 for a subsequent deployment for Boncuklu).

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC first year cost only $900 due to reusing existing module
evidence.verbatim_quote: Because the PAZC project was willing to reuse an existing module, their first year cost only $900 (a subsequent deployment cost $2,400, after they identified some additional modifications), illustrating the savings that redeployment can offer.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Three iterations of excavation module and two of survey module needed before functional MEMSAP system could be deployed
evidence.verbatim_quote: Ultimately only three iterations of the excavation module and two iterations of the survey module were needed before a functional system could be deployed in the field. However, this was likely because all of the data categories and relationships had been worked out—in paper version—over the course of previous field seasons.

evidence.evidence_text: PAZC module development completed in approximately three and a half weeks from first contact, with translation requiring less than one week
evidence.verbatim_quote: The total time that elapsed between first contact with FAIMS leadership and deployment of the finished PAZC module was approximately three and a half weeks. The FAIMS team translated the Boncuklu module into Spanish and customised it where required by editing the Boncuklu definition documents, a process that required less than one week after the requirements were fully specified.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items from same paragraph describing PAZC rapid development; timeline details support same claims

evidence.evidence_text: All project directors tested modules ahead of fieldwork but regretted not testing more thoroughly
evidence.verbatim_quote: All project directors tested their modules ahead of fieldwork, but eventually they all regretted not doing so more thoroughly, with more participants, and in more authentic situations.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn found significant problem with app design on first day of fieldwork that had slipped through earlier testing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Fairbairn, too, found a problem of fitness-to-purpose on the first day of fieldwork that had slipped through his earlier testing: 'A significant problem with the app design has arisen. It is one that I flagged earlier but somehow it got through my later checks . . .'.

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn received CSV data and created Access database before paper forms arrived in Australia
evidence.verbatim_quote: [I have received the CSV file and] the data are present and useable. I am now waiting for [the other project director] to send me the forms . . . (excerpted from Google Hangouts between Brian and Andrew Fairbairn, 18 September 2014)

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh reported FAIMS improved richness and integrity of PAZC data with more detailed context descriptions
evidence.verbatim_quote: our final review of data collected by the PAZC in 2014 suggests that using FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of our data. Context descriptions are generally more detailed, and the range of fields in the FAIMS default module meant that project members recorded types of data (such as parameters of soil matrices and inclusions) that we had formerly treated in an inconsistent fashion.

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson reported FAIMS data required less cleaning and organisation than transcribed data
evidence.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS data outputs [ . . . ] required [ . . . ] much less cleaning, organisation, and streamlining for consistency than transcribed data. [ . . . ] However, it was clear that once this initial hurdle was overcome it would be far faster and error-free to append FAIMS data from subsequent seasons onto these merged databases than to return to a paper form recording system.

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: MEMSAP survey tablets saved at least eight person-days of work
evidence.verbatim_quote: When the scope of data entry, cleaning, analysis, and archiving is considered, the tablets saved at least eight person-days of work, although this may have been an extreme case because one of the main post-season challenges [during previous seasons] was the integration of both paper and tablet data into a single database.

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu achieved 95% labour saving: 1–1.5 days post-processing with FAIMS vs 25–30 days without, equating to AU$5,000–10,000 per annum
evidence.verbatim_quote: The greatest gains in the FAIMS system were found after the excavation season was finished with post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records generated in a typical season. This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum. The benefits to the excavation project in financial/labour terms are hugely significant, equating to a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving.

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

consolidation_metadata.rationale: All three items from same paragraph reporting Fairbairn's quantified savings; form single integrated finding with time, cost, and percentage dimensions

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn discovered immediate digital data availability allowed timely discovery of errors
evidence.verbatim_quote: Finally, Fairbairn discovered an unexpected benefit of having his digital data available immediately: the timely discovery of errors. 'I also can see all the inconsistent entries that were made by people who should know better.'

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu FAIMS-in-a-box hardware worked well in harsh conditions with wifi providing 75-80% signal at 80m
evidence.verbatim_quote: Also, it is worth noting that the equipment—FAIMS-in-a-box—worked very well and with the exception of 1 tablet screen—cracked when an item fell on it from the edge of the trench—came through the season in great condition. This was in spite of very dusty conditions and a somewhat unreliable electricity supply. The server worked throughout and the [wifi] provided excellent coverage (75–80% signal strength at 80m, the furthest excavation trench.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Hardware durability and wifi coverage from same paragraph reporting Boncuklu local server experience

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh experienced upload speeds of 25 Kbps on online server - too slow for syncing
evidence.verbatim_quote: Using this system, our upload speeds consistently averaged 25 Kbps—too slow for syncing, even when tablets were left to do so overnight.

evidence.evidence_text: Context autonumbering caused exponential performance degradation with record input increasing from 20 minutes to over an hour
evidence.verbatim_quote: Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew (more precisely, as a square function of the number of records). More serious was the slowdown of the system halfway through its period of use. A record which initially took 20 minutes to input took over an hour due to slow syncing and updating.

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Both items from same paragraph describing performance problem; technical cause and user experience form integrated finding

evidence.evidence_text: Thompson reported digital recording enabled collection of more data and expanded interpretations
evidence.verbatim_quote: Thompson reported: 'Because FAIMS enabled data to be collected and processed so efficiently, we were able to collect more data, and this expanded the interpretations we could make from a field season of the same duration as when we used paper forms.'

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

evidence.evidence_text: Fairbairn reported digital recording opened dialogue about recording process and preserved previously undocumented interim fieldwork steps without changing substantive research goals
evidence.verbatim_quote: [I]mportantly, the technology has opened up a broader dialogue about the recording process, increased awareness in the excavation group of the challenges and requirements of recording and opened a quite fixed system to change. [W]e have had a very archaic use of 'official site photos' which are of the cleaned up contexts. Well, now everyone can take images as they go, including as contexts are under excavation (rather than tidy-for-archive shots) and this improves the chances of understanding the features and contexts we see. [S]o far conversion [to digital recording] has not changed our substantive research goals.

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

consolidation_metadata.rationale: Three consecutive Fairbairn observations about digital recording impact; form integrated assessment of process, documentation, and research continuity

evidence.evidence_text: VanValkenburgh noted digital data availability will facilitate making data publicly accessible in approximately two years
evidence.verbatim_quote: Looking even further ahead, digitally born data makes the timely publication of datasets more likely: 'the ready availability . . . of our digital data is going to greatly facilitate making it publicly accessible in approximately two years.'

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

evidence.evidence_text: Two small projects by doctoral students successfully customised and deployed their own FAIMS systems
evidence.verbatim_quote: Two small projects, both undertaken by doctoral students, have successfully customised and deployed their own systems.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

evidence.evidence_text: Boncuklu's single context may resolve within less than 5 cm of deposit due to fine layering
evidence.verbatim_quote: One peculiarity of the site is its extremely fine layering and the complex intercutting of archaeological features, caused by rebuilding of houses on the same site time and time again. . . . [a single context in] Boncuklu may be resolved within <5 cm of deposit.

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

claims.claim_text: The FAIMS project successfully developed national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology and related disciplines
claims.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project is a university-based, e-research initiative that was launched in 2012 to develop national, domain-wide information management infrastructure for archaeology and related disciplines

claims.claim_text: Field deployment experience informed ongoing FAIMS development resulting in production-quality software
claims.verbatim_quote: Experience from these deployments informed ongoing development of FAIMS software, resulting in the release of FAIMS 2.0, the current production version, in November 2014

claims.claim_text: FAIMS can be deployed at reasonable cost with multiple service options to fit different project resources
claims.verbatim_quote: It is our hope that by building free and open-source software to high standards using research infrastructure funding, by providing extensive documentation and as much support as possible for do-it-yourselfers, by building a library of modules for various activities, and by offering customisation, deployment, and support services at a reasonable cost, we can deliver purpose-built field-recording software to projects and organisations who otherwise could not afford it.

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

claims.claim_text: Module reuse enables rapid deployment with lower costs than new development
claims.verbatim_quote: The speed of production was possible because of VanValkenburgh's pragmatism and willingness to adapt an existing module. As this example illustrates, a system with a generalised core can spawn new deployments rapidly in a way that neither bespoke nor general-purpose systems can.

claims.claim_text: Converting from paper to digital workflows forces explicit articulation of implicit recording knowledge
claims.verbatim_quote: Converting from paper to digital workflows is an involved and time-consuming process. It requires making the implicit knowledge embedded in paper forms explicit.

claims.claim_text: Established projects with stable procedures have advantages during software customisation because they can articulate requirements quickly
claims.verbatim_quote: Established projects with stable procedures have an advantage during software customisation, since they can articulate requirements and priorities quickly and coherently. Even so, field projects with complex workflows still require several months for development to ensure that the end product satisfies their needs.

claims.claim_text: Testing must be thorough, involve multiple participants, and occur under authentic field conditions to ensure fitness-for-purpose
claims.verbatim_quote: Test your module and, if you are using multiple tablets, the server and its system extensively before you depart for the field with real data including every field and recording type you may use; bugs may be hard to find and you need to be sure the system works for your needs.

claims.claim_text: Digital field recording produces clean, rich data available immediately after fieldwork without extensive digitisation effort
claims.verbatim_quote: an entire season's data could be retrieved immediately, without tedious digitisation and the errors it inevitably introduces

claims.claim_text: FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of field data compared to paper recording
claims.verbatim_quote: our final review of data collected by the PAZC in 2014 suggests that using FAIMS improved both the richness and integrity of our data.

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Time and cost savings from digital recording offset upfront investment in development and testing
claims.verbatim_quote: While many projects prefer to collect data first and spend effort cleaning it later, our partners chose to invest effort before fieldwork, in order to have cleaner, richer data for immediate analysis. Learning the capabilities of FAIMS software and engaging in the scoping and testing required by co-development all took more time before fieldwork than producing paper forms would have. After fieldwork, however, they got rich, well-structured data at the push of a button

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Digital data availability enables timely discovery and correction of errors that would otherwise go undetected until later digitisation
claims.verbatim_quote: His data was digital and ready for review promptly at the end of the season, which revealed problems that would otherwise have gone undetected until the paper forms were digitised—perhaps months later—when the errors would have been far more difficult to correct. Even when digital data creation does not prevent errors, it exposes them.

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

claims.claim_text: Local dedicated hardware servers are more reliable and faster than online servers for field deployment despite higher cost
claims.verbatim_quote: Local, dedicated hardware servers are more expensive than online servers, and they require that users test and maintain them, but they are faster and more robust than online servers.

claims.claim_text: Trade-offs between features and performance have serious consequences when recording systems are deployed under field stress
claims.verbatim_quote: The shared responsibilities of developers and researchers are perhaps clearest in the context of the trade-offs between features and performance that must be made during the production of a field recording system. Each of these choices can have serious consequences when the final system is put under the stress of a full deployment.

claims.claim_text: Digital recording improves quantity, quality, and availability of data with potential long-term benefits for reproducibility and data dissemination
claims.verbatim_quote: More continuous recordkeeping, including of 'messy' work-in-progress, not only helps researchers at a later time better understand what they have excavated, but may contribute toward both making workflows more transparent and 'openly exposing the process of research' (Kansa, Ch. 4.2), thus improving the reproducibility and professionalism of field research.

location.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

claims.claim_text: FAIMS sustainability depends on infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions supplemented by growing service fee revenue
claims.verbatim_quote: We envision that within five years, service fees will constitute perhaps 25% of our budget, but the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions.

claims.claim_text: Generalised open-source tools like FAIMS bring advantages of bespoke software within reach of typical projects
claims.verbatim_quote: Generalised, open-source tools designed for field research bring the advantages of bespoke software within reach of 'typical' projects.

claims.claim_text: Co-development between archaeologists and software developers is difficult but productive and yields effective fit-to-purpose systems
claims.verbatim_quote: Software co-development in a generalised framework like FAIMS, involving a genuine partnership between archaeologists and technologists, is a difficult but productive process that can yield systems that are effective and fit-to-purpose.

claims.claim_text: Generalised software allows archaeologists to participate in software development rather than merely consume software
claims.verbatim_quote: Perhaps more importantly, generalised tools also allow archaeologists to participate in software development, not merely consume software. Such co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and a software development team.

claims.claim_text: High-quality timely support is essential for deploying new technology in the field
claims.verbatim_quote: Exceptional support is necessary when deploying new technology in the field, especially software that is purpose-built for the research community

claims.claim_text: FAIMS provides fieldwork-specific capabilities that general-purpose database software cannot match
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS offers similar optimisation for other issues specific to fieldwork, such as the need to collect a variety of data, work in multilingual settings, and promote the production of compatible datasets for large-scale, synthetic research.

claims.claim_text: Bespoke applications are beyond the resources of all but the best-funded projects due to high development and maintenance costs
claims.verbatim_quote: A bespoke Android or iOS app, if properly resourced and designed, may outperform FAIMS for any single data collection task, but at considerable cost. The requirements gathering, planning, development, and testing required to produce software reliable enough for field archaeology are expensive and demanding.

claims.claim_text: FAIMS treats each deployment as an authentic miniature software development project requiring proper scoping, coding, and quality assurance
claims.verbatim_quote: FAIMS treats complex archaeological work with the seriousness it deserves. The FAIMS approach, partly dictated by the nature of the software and partly by our experience, has us treat each deployment as an authentic, miniature software development project that requires proper 'scoping' (requirements gathering, software design, and development planning), coding, and 'quality assurance' (testing at each step of development to ensure that software works and is fit-to-purpose).

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The authors assume that their three case studies are representative of typical archaeological projects adopting FAIMS, and that lessons from these deployments generalise to other contexts
trigger_text: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork.
Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects.

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation
Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper presents three case studies as demonstrating 'common challenges, concerns, and benefits' without discussing potential selection bias (all three projects had relationships with FAIMS team through LIEF funding or direct payment). The assumption that these partner projects represent typical adoption experiences is never explicitly justified.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The authors assume that quantified time savings (95% labour reduction) are directly comparable across paper vs digital workflows without accounting for hidden costs of digital system maintenance
trigger_text: a total of 1–1.5 days of handling time using FAIMS against 25–30 days when not in use per annum, in other words a 95% labour saving
This saving in paid RA time equates to c. AU$5,000–10,000 per annum

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data
The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper quantifies post-fieldwork savings but does not include ongoing costs of tablet maintenance, software updates, server hosting, or FAIMS team support fees in the comparison. The 95% figure compares only post-excavation data handling time, not total lifecycle costs.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The authors assume that open-source software business models remain viable long-term for research infrastructure, despite evidence that 95% of funding comes from grants rather than service fees
trigger_text: To date, fees have accounted for about 5% of the FAIMS budget, with infrastructure grants constituting the other 95%
We envision that within five years, service fees will constitute perhaps 25% of our budget, but the project will likely remain largely dependent upon infrastructure grants and in-kind contributions
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The sustainability claim rests on anticipated growth in service fees, but the projection (5% to 25% in five years) is not supported by trend data or market analysis. The reliance on competitive infrastructure grants introduces funding uncertainty not explicitly acknowledged as a risk.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The authors assume that Android device heterogeneity is a manageable trade-off for openness, despite evidence of device-specific bugs requiring per-device testing
trigger_text: These compatibility problems are the price paid for the wide range of devices offered within the Android ecosystem.
It therefore proved necessary to test the FAIMS mobile platform on each device.
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper acknowledges device-specific bugs as a 'price paid' but does not quantify the testing burden this creates for projects, nor discuss whether the openness benefits outweigh the testing costs for typical archaeological projects with limited technical resources.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The paper bridges from individual project successes to generalisable claims about digital archaeology benefits without addressing potential survivorship bias or publication bias
trigger_text: project directors nonetheless reiterated that enhanced speed, accuracy, consistency, and granularity represent important contributions of digital recording to archaeological interpretation
based on their experience, most projects would likely come out ahead

trigger_locations.section: Theme 3: Digital Recording and Archaeological Interpretation

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The conclusion that 'most projects would likely come out ahead' extrapolates from three partner projects (who paid for or received support from FAIMS) to the broader archaeological community. Failed deployments or projects that abandoned FAIMS are not discussed.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: The authors assume that co-development model scalability will not be constrained by FAIMS team capacity as user base grows
trigger_text: we have created 19 workflows for 17 projects and supported 11 of them in the field since the public release of our software in November 2013. That number is likely to double by the end of 2017.
Only the availability of high-quality and timely support can provide the peace of mind necessary for archaeologists to risk moving from commercial software to new systems

trigger_locations.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper emphasises that high-quality support is essential for adoption, while also projecting doubling of projects served. How the team will scale support capacity to match doubled demand without proportional funding increase is not addressed.

research_designs.design_description: Three-case multiple case study design examining FAIMS deployments across diverse archaeological projects to identify common themes and lessons
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Three researchers, one from each case-study site, generously offered to share and discuss their experiences deploying FAIMS during 2014 fieldwork. They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork. These sources provide the quotations below; their complete, unedited communications with the FAIMS project are available via the digital supplement to this volume

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

research_designs.rationale: Multiple case study design enables thematic synthesis across diverse deployment contexts while preserving project-specific details
expected_information_missing: Case selection criteria not explicitly stated
No discussion of why three cases were chosen (saturation, representativeness)
No acknowledgment of potential selection bias from partner relationships

research_designs.design_description: Organisation of case study findings into three cross-cutting themes rather than presenting cases separately
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects.

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

research_designs.rationale: Thematic organisation highlights shared patterns across diverse contexts rather than individual project narratives
expected_information_missing: Process for identifying themes not described
No discussion of analyst triangulation or member checking

research_designs.design_description: Strategic choice to structure FAIMS deployment as collaborative co-development between archaeologists and software developers rather than vendor-client relationship
research_designs.verbatim_quote: Such co-development involves a partnership between field archaeologists and a software development team. This partnership can ease the transitions from paper to digital fieldwork, illuminate the advantages digital approaches offer, and ensure that software is fit-to-purpose.
research_designs.rationale: Co-development model ensures archaeological domain requirements shape software rather than archaeologists adapting to generic software
expected_information_missing: Responsibility allocation between partners not systematically documented

research_designs.design_description: Strategic positioning of FAIMS between general-purpose database software and bespoke applications to balance customisability with affordability
research_designs.verbatim_quote: FAIMS lies near the middle of this spectrum. Compared to a general-purpose DBMS, FAIMS is 'generalised' in the sense it has no predetermined data schemas or user interface, instead offering a degree of control over data structures and forms similar to DBMSes like Microsoft Access or FileMaker Pro. It is not general-purpose, however, in that it has been purpose built to perform well under difficult field conditions
research_designs.rationale: Generalised approach provides domain-specific functionality while distributing development costs across user community
expected_information_missing: Selection criteria for 'generalised' positioning not quantified

research_designs.design_description: Strategic choice to use open-source licensing with mixed funding model combining infrastructure grants and service fees
research_designs.verbatim_quote: This infrastructure grant income is supplemented by fees charged for customisation, field support, server hosting, and other services (a typical open-source business model; cf. Raymond 2001: 136; Popp 2015); the United States–based project discussed here paid for services directly.
research_designs.rationale: Open-source model enables community contribution while service fees provide revenue diversification beyond grants
expected_information_missing: Risk analysis for grant-dependent model not provided

research_designs.design_description: Case studies are based on retrospective post-project reflection rather than prospective study design with pre-registered outcomes
trigger_text: After fieldwork, the FAIMS team asked each of the project directors to reflect on the design, development, and deployment of their module, and tell us what they found the most worthwhile payoff for their efforts.
They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

research_designs.inference_reasoning: The paper relies on retrospective self-reporting from project directors after fieldwork completion. This design choice is never explicitly stated as a methodological decision, but is implicit in the data collection approach. The retrospective nature introduces potential recall bias and rationalisation effects that would not occur in prospective designs.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: No discussion of limitations of retrospective design versus prospective study; no acknowledgment of potential recall bias or post-hoc rationalisation in project director reflections
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether positive outcomes were predicted in advance or rationalised retrospectively

expected_information_missing: Timing of questionnaire administration relative to fieldwork not specified
No discussion of retrospective design limitations
Pre-fieldwork expectations not documented for comparison

methods.method_description: Structured questionnaires completed by project directors after fieldwork to capture deployment experiences
methods.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork.

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

expected_information_missing: Question wording and structure not specified

methods.method_description: Analysis of email and chat communications between project directors and FAIMS team before, during, and after fieldwork
methods.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires, and also exchanged many emails and chat messages with the FAIMS team before, during, and after their fieldwork. These sources provide the quotations below; their complete, unedited communications with the FAIMS project are available via the digital supplement to this volume

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

expected_information_missing: Selection criteria for quoted communications not specified
Coding approach for communications not described

methods.method_description: Iterative adaptation of FAIMS core software through modification of XML definition documents to meet project-specific requirements
methods.verbatim_quote: Such a 'deployment' involves tailoring the core software by creating or modifying 'definition documents,' primarily Extensible Markup Language (XML) files, which produce customised data collection 'modules' (Ross et al. 2015). Each module accommodates specific data and workflow requirements, as required by different approaches to archaeological survey, excavation, and artefact processing.
expected_information_missing: Quality criteria for module acceptance not defined

methods.method_description: Scoping process to elicit and formalise archaeological recording requirements from project personnel
methods.verbatim_quote: Requirements gathering, planning, and development is a lengthy, iterative process that requires frequent communication, consultation, and feedback. Established projects with stable procedures have an advantage during software customisation, since they can articulate requirements and priorities quickly and coherently.

methods.method_description: Multi-stage testing approach including pre-fieldwork testing and field deployment testing
methods.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS approach, partly dictated by the nature of the software and partly by our experience, has us treat each deployment as an authentic, miniature software development project that requires proper 'scoping' (requirements gathering, software design, and development planning), coding, and 'quality assurance' (testing at each step of development to ensure that software works and is fit-to-purpose).

methods.method_description: Use of GitHub for collaborative module development, version tracking, and community sharing
methods.verbatim_quote: The FAIMS project uses GitHub, an online version control tool for collaborative software development, to publish and manage individual modules (https://github.com/FAIMS; cf. Ross et al. 2015). Software or other text documents stored on GitHub can be downloaded, edited, copied, and adapted at will.
expected_information_missing: Pull request review process not described

methods.method_description: Retrospective comparison of time and cost metrics between digital and paper-based workflows
methods.verbatim_quote: Fairbairn also quantified the time-savings and cost-benefit of clean, born-digital data to his project: 'The greatest gains in the FAIMS system were found after the excavation season was finished with post-processing of the data and checking taking 2–3 hours in comparison to several hundred hours for entry of the >300 context records generated in a typical season.'

location.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

expected_information_missing: Comparison methodology not standardised across projects

methods.method_description: Process used to identify and organise case study observations into three thematic categories
trigger_text: Their observations can be woven into three themes, demonstrating common challenges, concerns, and benefits shared across all three projects.
One of the themes that emerged from these case studies involves the shift in time and energy

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

methods.inference_reasoning: The paper presents three themes as having 'emerged' from case studies and observations being 'woven' into themes, implying some form of qualitative analysis. However, no coding methodology, analytical framework, or theme development process is documented. The reader cannot determine how themes were identified, who performed the analysis, or what criteria distinguished themes.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Theme identification methodology not specified - unknown whether themes were predetermined or emerged inductively, whether multiple analysts coded data, or what criteria defined thematic boundaries
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot evaluate rigour of thematic analysis or whether alternative thematic structures were considered

methods.method_description: Process for selecting quotations from communications to include in paper
trigger_text: These sources provide the quotations below
their complete, unedited communications with the FAIMS project are available via the digital supplement to this volume

trigger_locations.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation
Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

methods.inference_reasoning: The paper states quotations were drawn from communications and that full communications are available in supplements. This implies a selection process occurred to choose which quotes to feature. The criteria for selecting illustrative quotes versus leaving them in supplements is not documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Quote selection criteria not specified - unknown whether quotes were selected to represent typical views, exceptional cases, or to support specific arguments
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether quoted material is representative of overall communication content

expected_information_missing: Selection criteria for quotations not specified
Representativeness of selected quotes not discussed
Volume of total communications not quantified for context

protocols.protocol_description: Post-project questionnaire administered to project directors
protocols.verbatim_quote: They took the time to complete post-project questionnaires

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

protocols.protocol_description: Documentation and preservation of project director communications for analysis
protocols.verbatim_quote: their complete, unedited communications with the FAIMS project are available via the digital supplement to this volume (see the files contained in Supplementary Material 1: 'Fairbairn: Boncuklu Case Study'; 'Fairbairn: Chat Log.pdf'; 'Thompson: Malawi Case Study'; 'VanValkenburgh: PAZC Case Study').

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

protocols.protocol_description: GitHub-based procedure for duplicating and adapting existing modules for new projects
protocols.verbatim_quote: As an example, in 2013, the FAIMS team developed a 'deluxe excavation' module, which provided the foundation for the three deployments discussed here (Boncuklu Höyük in central Turkey, the Malawi Earlier-Middle Stone Age Project (MEMSAP), and Proyecto Arqueológico Zaña Colonial (PAZC) in Peru). This module was duplicated ('forked') and modified to meet the needs of each project.
steps: Modify definition documents for project requirements
Pull useful changes back to original module

protocols.protocol_description: Four-level hierarchy of customisation approaches with progressive complexity
protocols.verbatim_quote: After the establishment of a server, do-it-yourself users can customise the mobile application for their own work in four ways, which require progressively more effort and technical expertise, but also allow more nuanced control over the resulting module: 1. Reuse an existing module as-is, which requires only downloading the application from Google Play and selecting the desired module from a list; 2. Use Heurist (an online data service), which provides a graphic user interface for the generation of definition documents (suitable for relatively simple modules); 3. Use a simplified module generator, which requires writing a single XML file that generates definition documents (suitable for modules of moderate complexity); 4. Modify an existing module, or create a new one, by editing the definition documents directly, which requires proficiency with XML and BeanShell (a scripting language).

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

steps: Level 1: Download from Google Play, select module
Level 2: Use Heurist GUI to generate definition documents
Level 3: Write single XML file using simplified generator
Level 4: Edit definition documents directly (XML + BeanShell)
expected_information_missing: Decision criteria for selecting customisation level not specified
Effort estimates per level not quantified

protocols.protocol_description: Consultation process with project personnel to define data categories and module layout
protocols.verbatim_quote: Prior to the field season, the FAIMS leadership team met with several of its partners at UQ, including those involved in MEMSAP. . . . Several hours were spent in discussions with all senior project personnel to ensure that all data types they wanted recorded were represented in the modules, and then after the workshop detailed plans for the tab layout and controls were developed mainly by the project leader but in consultation with other project personnel.
steps: Discussion of data types to be recorded
Development of tab layout and controls by project leader
Consultation with other personnel on detailed plans

protocols.protocol_description: Pre-deployment testing protocol for modules and hardware
protocols.verbatim_quote: Test your module and, if you are using multiple tablets, the server and its system extensively before you depart for the field with real data including every field and recording type you may use; bugs may be hard to find and you need to be sure the system works for your needs.
steps: Test all fields and recording types

protocols.protocol_description: GitHub-based workflow for module publication and collaborative development
protocols.verbatim_quote: Using GitHub not only made the definition documents for all four modules (the original plus the three adaptations) publicly available, but it also allowed for the most useful changes to each of the derivative modules to be incorporated ('pulled') back into the original 'deluxe excavation' module. Users can now choose whichever of these four modules best fits the requirements of their own fieldwork (the three customised modules can be found in the Supplementary Material folder).
steps: Allow download, editing, copying, and adaptation
Incorporate useful changes via pull requests
Maintain module library for user selection

protocols.protocol_description: Three hardware configuration options for FAIMS server deployment
protocols.verbatim_quote: In the case studies presented below, Boncuklu and MEMSAP purchased preconfigured local servers, while PAZC used an online server (but later switched to a local server in a subsequent season).

location.section: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform

expected_information_missing: Decision criteria for server selection not formalised

protocols.protocol_description: Archaeological recording methodology used at case study sites documenting individual stratigraphic contexts
protocols.verbatim_quote: As a result, excavation has necessarily been fine-grained, utilising a single context recording method better to understand the subtle interrelationships of the site's building sequences and extra-mural areas. Single context recording describes each deposit, cut and feature in detail, including spatial coordinates and contexts (artefacts, samples) as well as basic descriptives (form, size, etc).

location.section: Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation

protocols.protocol_description: FAIMS team procedure for extracting CSV files from data archives for project directors
trigger_text: Post-processing required specialist input by FAIMS to extract CSV files from the data tarball [.tar, a common Linux file archive similar to .zip], but the outcome was easily accessible and useable data which can be uploaded to a database.

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

protocols.inference_reasoning: Fairbairn's quote indicates that data export required 'specialist input by FAIMS' to extract CSV files, implying a technical procedure was performed. This procedure is mentioned as having occurred but no details are provided about what the extraction process involves, why specialist input was required, or what steps were taken.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Data export procedure not documented - unknown what 'specialist input' involved, whether this was automated or manual, or what data transformations occurred during extraction
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess data integrity through export process or whether data could be extracted without FAIMS team involvement

expected_information_missing: Extraction commands or scripts not provided

protocols.protocol_description: Monitoring of system performance during field deployment to detect degradation
trigger_text: Performance degradation was barely perceptible during testing, which involved only a few records, but it worsened exponentially as the database grew
A record which initially took 20 minutes to input took over an hour due to slow syncing and updating
protocols.inference_reasoning: The paper reports specific performance metrics (20 minutes initial input time increasing to over an hour, degradation as square function of records) implying systematic observation of performance. However, no monitoring protocol is described - unknown whether this was systematic measurement or ad-hoc user observation, what metrics were tracked, or how degradation was quantified.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Performance monitoring methodology not specified - unknown whether timing was measured systematically, what metrics were recorded, or whether performance data was logged automatically or observed informally
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess reliability of performance claims or compare across deployments

protocols.protocol_description: Process for reviewing digital data to identify recording errors and inconsistencies
trigger_text: His data was digital and ready for review promptly at the end of the season, which revealed problems that would otherwise have gone undetected
I also can see all the inconsistent entries that were made by people who should know better

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data
The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

protocols.inference_reasoning: Fairbairn reports discovering errors through data review, implying some review process occurred. The nature of this review - whether it was systematic quality assurance or ad-hoc browsing, what criteria defined 'inconsistent entries', and whether errors were logged or just noted - is not documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Error detection methodology not specified - unknown whether systematic validation rules were applied, what constituted an 'error' versus acceptable variation, or whether error rates were quantified
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess data quality levels or compare error rates across recording methods

protocols.protocol_description: Post-fieldwork data cleaning and organisation procedures applied to FAIMS outputs
trigger_text: The FAIMS data outputs [ . . . ] required [ . . . ] much less cleaning, organisation, and streamlining for consistency than transcribed data
There were fewer errors made in data recording with the tablets

trigger_locations.subsection: The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data
The Payoff: Clean, Granular, Digital Data

protocols.inference_reasoning: Thompson's report that FAIMS data required 'much less cleaning, organisation, and streamlining' implies that some cleaning still occurred. The nature of this cleaning - what transformations were applied, what errors were corrected, and what standards data were cleaned to - is not documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Data cleaning procedures not specified - unknown what cleaning operations were performed, what proportion of data required cleaning, or what quality standards were applied
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess final data quality or determine what transformations occurred between raw data and analysed data

expected_information_missing: Proportion of data cleaned not quantified

protocols.protocol_description: Training of field personnel in use of FAIMS modules and tablets
trigger_text: Training a project novice in the use of the module is where potential misunderstandings (of the workflow) become apparent
Simulation of fieldwork is highly advised here
protocols.inference_reasoning: Thompson recommends training novices and simulating fieldwork, implying training occurred but acknowledging it was inadequate. The actual training procedures used - duration, content, format, assessment of competency - are not documented.

implicit_metadata.transparency_gap: Training procedures not documented - unknown what training was provided, how long it lasted, what competencies were assessed, or whether all field personnel received equivalent training
implicit_metadata.assessability_impact: Cannot assess whether recording quality variation relates to training variation

paper_doi.notes: Book chapter in edited volume. No DOI assigned to individual chapter.

author_orcids.notes: No ORCIDs found in extracted text. Publication year 2016 predates widespread ORCID adoption in HASS disciplines.

software_pids.name: FAIMS Mobile Platform
software_pids.notes: GitHub repository URL provided, no DOI or Software Heritage identifier

pid_graph_summary.notes: Only software repository URL present. No paper DOI (book chapter), no author ORCIDs, no dataset DOIs. Low PID connectivity typical for 2016 book chapter.

funding.funder_name: National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR)
funding.verbatim_text: funded by a grant from the Australian National eResearch Collaboration Tools and Resources (NeCTAR) eResearch Tools program (RT043; AUD $949,500)

funding.amount: AUD $945,000 total ARC funding and university co-investment
funding.verbatim_text: Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Infrastructure Equipment and Facilities (LIEF) award (LE140100151; AUD $945,000 total ARC funding and university co-investment)

data_availability.verbatim_statement: No formal data availability statement. Supplementary materials referenced but access mechanism unclear.
data_availability.notes: Paper references 'Supplementary Material 1' containing case study communications and module files, but no repository URL or access mechanism provided. The GitHub repository (https://github.com/FAIMS) hosts module definition documents, not research data.

code_availability.verbatim_statement: The FAIMS project uses GitHub, an online version control tool for collaborative software development, to publish and manage individual modules (https://github.com/FAIMS; cf. Ross et al. 2015). Software or other text documents stored on GitHub can be downloaded, edited, copied, and adapted at will.
code_availability.notes: Open source software on GitHub with GPLv3 licence. Core FAIMS software and module definition documents publicly available. No version-specific DOI or archival identifier.

author_contributions.notes: No author contribution statement. Paper authored by FAIMS team members (Sobotkova, Ross, Ballsun-Stanton) and three case study project directors (Fairbairn, Thompson, VanValkenburgh). Roles inferable from text but not formally documented.

conflicts_of_interest.notes: No conflicts of interest statement. Potential conflict: three authors are FAIMS team members reporting on FAIMS software; three are project directors who received FAIMS services.

ethics_approval.notes: No ethics statement. Paper describes software deployment and case study experiences, not human subjects research. Archaeological fieldwork conducted by partner projects would have separate ethics/permit requirements not detailed here.

permits_and_authorizations.notes: No permits documented in paper. Paper describes FAIMS software deployment, not direct archaeological fieldwork. Case study sites (Boncuklu, MEMSAP, PAZC) would have separate excavation permits not within scope of this software-focused paper.

preregistration.notes: No preregistration. Study type (software deployment case studies) not typically preregistered.

supplementary_materials.notes: Supplementary materials referenced but access mechanism not clearly specified. Publisher is The Digital Press at the University of North Dakota (open access academic press).

references_completeness.notes: References section truncated in extracted text. Based on visible references, most lack DOIs (typical for 2016 publication and book chapter format).

findable.rationale: Software has GitHub URL but no DOI. GitHub provides some indexing. No rich metadata schema, no PID in metadata.

accessible.rationale: GitHub uses HTTPS (standard protocol). Software is open source (GPLv3) and freely accessible. No authentication barriers. Metadata persistence unclear if GitHub repository deleted.

interoperable.rationale: Software uses XML definition documents (structured format). No formal vocabulary integration documented. No qualified references to other resources.

reusable.rationale: GitHub provides README and documentation. GPLv3 licence explicit. Provenance through GitHub history. Follows open source community standards.

machine_actionability.rationale: GitHub repository accessible via git clone but no DOI-based resolution, no structured metadata API, no formal dataset registration.

discipline_context.expectations_rationale: Pre-2017 publication predates widespread FAIR adoption in HASS. Book chapter format typically lacks DOIs for individual chapters. GitHub hosting for software was progressive for 2016. Score of 9/16 (56%) above expectations for 2016 HASS book chapter.

recommendations: Archive software release on Zenodo to obtain DOI
Add CodeMeta or Citation File Format (CITATION.cff) to repository
Link ORCID identifiers for authors in repository metadata
Document supplementary materials access mechanism clearly

pass0_metadata.notes: Book chapter in edited volume. Citation block provides full bibliographic information. Six authors listed with full names.

sections_extracted: Customising and Deploying the FAIMS Mobile Platform
Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation
pass1_claims_evidence.strategy: Liberal extraction with comprehensive capture of quantitative observations and project director quotes. Methodological claims extracted from both FAIMS team exposition and case study reports.
known_uncertainties: Cost figures reported in AUD without inflation adjustment or date specification
Time savings quantified by single project (Boncuklu) may not generalise
Self-reported case study data from project partners with vested interest in positive outcomes
pass1_claims_evidence.paper_structure: Methodological case study with three embedded case reports. Thematic synthesis across cases rather than separate case narratives.

notes: Claims C018-C022 retained without direct evidence support as they represent methodological arguments from authors rather than case study findings
All bidirectional references updated after consolidation

pass3_rdmap.extraction_strategy: Liberal explicit RDMAP extraction from Introduction, FAIMS Project, FAIMS Mobile Platform, Customising and Deploying, Between Off-the-Shelf, Nature of Co-Development, Three Case Studies, and Theme 1-3 sections
sections_extracted: The FAIMS Mobile Platform + Customising and Deploying (~1200 words)
Between Off-the-Shelf and Bespoke Software + The Nature of Co-Development (~900 words)
Three Case Studies and Three Themes of Observation + Theme 1 (~1500 words)
known_uncertainties: Questionnaire instrument not provided - protocol details sparse
Testing procedures mentioned but not systematically documented
Case selection criteria implicit rather than explicit
Unclear boundary between FAIMS team methods and partner project methods
tier_assignment_notes: RD001-RD005: Strategic choices about case study design, partnership model, software positioning, and sustainability
M001-M007: Tactical approaches for data collection, customisation, testing, and analysis
P001-P009: Operational procedures including questionnaires, GitHub workflows, testing steps, and server deployment

pass4_implicit_rdmap.scan_methodology: Systematic 4-pattern scan across all major sections (Introduction, FAIMS Project, Mobile Platform, Customising and Deploying, Between Off-the-Shelf, Nature of Co-Development, Three Case Studies, Theme 1-3, Conclusions) for each RDMAP tier
patterns_applied: Pattern 4: Strategic positioning without explicit statement
key_transparency_gaps: Data export procedure mentioned but not detailed (P-IMP-001)
Error detection and data cleaning procedures undocumented (P-IMP-003, P-IMP-004)
Training procedures mentioned but not specified (P-IMP-005)
notes: Paper is primarily methodological advocacy rather than empirical research, so some undocumented procedures relate to case study reporting rather than FAIMS system itself
Retrospective design (RD-IMP-001) is significant as it shapes all reported outcomes
Theme identification lack of documentation (M-IMP-001) particularly impacts credibility of thematic synthesis claims

rationalisation_analysis.research_designs: All 6 designs represent independent strategic decisions: multiple case study approach (RD001), thematic synthesis organisation (RD002), co-development model (RD003), generalised software positioning (RD004), open-source sustainability (RD005), and retrospective reporting design (RD-IMP-001). Each requires independent transparency assessment.
rationalisation_analysis.methods: All 9 methods serve distinct analytical purposes. M001 (questionnaire) and M002 (communication analysis) are complementary data collection approaches. M003-M006 form a software development workflow but each addresses different assessment criteria. M007 is distinct comparative analysis. Implicit methods M-IMP-001 (theme identification) and M-IMP-002 (quote selection) address different qualitative analysis gaps.
rationalisation_analysis.protocols: 14 protocols maintained at appropriate granularity. P003 (forking) and P007 (version control) considered for consolidation but kept separate as they address different operations (module adaptation vs publishing/sharing). All implicit protocols (P-IMP-001 through P-IMP-005) address distinct transparency gaps requiring separate assessment.

cross_reference_verification.orphan_check: No orphaned items - all RDMAP items connected to design-method-protocol hierarchy
cross_reference_verification.bidirectional_consistency: Verified - all forward references have corresponding reverse references

tier_verification.research_designs: All 6 items answer WHY questions about strategic research decisions - confirmed as correct tier
tier_verification.methods: All 9 items answer WHAT questions about tactical approaches - confirmed as correct tier
tier_verification.protocols: All 14 items answer HOW questions about operational procedures - confirmed as correct tier

notes: Zero consolidation reflects appropriate granularity from Pass 3-4 extraction
27% implicit ratio within normal range (20-40%) indicates thorough implicit scanning
Paper's methodological advocacy nature means many RDMAP items describe FAIMS approach rather than case study research methods
Distinct separation maintained between explicit documented procedures and implicit mentioned-but-undocumented procedures
